message_1: A factory has a production line that produces 5000 widgets each day. They have 3 machines that can produce these widgets, but the machines have different efficiencies. Machine 1 can produce 1000 widgets per day in 5 hours, machine 2 can produce 1500 widgets per day in 7.5 hours, and machine 3 can produce 2000 widgets per day in 10 hours. The factory wants to optimize its production by allocating the machines in the most efficient way possible. How many hours should each machine be used every day to produce the maximum number of widgets?
message_2:
To determine the most efficient way to allocate the machines, we need to calculate the production rate (widgets per hour) of each machine.

Machine 1: 1000 widgets / 5 hours = 200 widgets per hour
Machine 2: 1500 widgets / 7.5 hours = 200 widgets per hour
Machine 3: 2000 widgets / 10 hours = 200 widgets per hour

Surprisingly, all three machines have the same production rate of 200 widgets per hour. Therefore, to produce 5000 widgets per day, the factory can allocate the machines in any combination as long as the total production time is 25 hours (5000 widgets / 200 widgets per hour).

One possible allocation is to use each machine for the same amount of time. In this case, each machine would be used for 25 hours / 3 machines = 8.33 hours (approximately) per day.
